line: To Wash It All
label: heading

line: James mickens
label: heading

line: This is my last column! Thanks
label: paragraph

line: for reading, and thanks for all
label: paragraph

line: of the support :-). never forget
label: paragraph

line: that when you are alone, i
label: paragraph

line: am with you, and when you
label: paragraph

line: are with someone else, i am also with you,
label: paragraph

line: because i think that i am better than that other
label: paragraph

line: person and i have lengthy opinions about why
label: paragraph

line: Away
label: heading

line: W hen I was in graduate school in Ann Arbor, I had a friend who
label: paragraph

line: was deeply involved with the environmentalist movement. He
label: paragraph

line: purchased his food from local farmers’ markets, and he com-
label: paragraph

line: muted by bike instead of by car to reduce his carbon footprint, and he main-
label: paragraph

line: tained a horrid compost bin that will probably be the origin of the next flu
label: paragraph

line: pandemic. One day, he told me that he was going to visit a farm for a week.
label: paragraph

line: I asked him why, and he said that he wanted to “get closer to the land,” a
label: paragraph

line: phrase that you can only say with a straight face if you’re narrating a docu-
label: paragraph

line: mentary about ancient South American tribes. I told my friend that the land
label: paragraph

line: didn’t want to get closer to him, and if he really looked at the land, he’d see
label: paragraph

line: that it was not composed of delicious organic trail mix, but famine and
label: paragraph

line: vultures and backbreaking labor involving wheelbarrows and generally
label: paragraph

line: un acceptable quantities of insects. He responded with an extended lecture
label: paragraph

line: about eco-responsibility, a lecture that I immediately forgot because I real-
label: paragraph

line: ized that my naïve friend was going to die on that farm. So, I told my friend
label: paragraph

line: that he shouldn’t be afraid to end his trip early if he wasn’t having a good
label: paragraph

line: time. He smiled at me, the way that people in slasher movies smile before
label: paragraph

line: they get chopped up, and he left for the farm. Precisely 37 hours later, he
label: paragraph

line: called me on the phone. I asked him how everything was going, and he made
label: paragraph

line: a haunting, elegiac noise, like a foghorn calling out for its mate. I asked him
label: paragraph

line: to describe his first day, and he said that his entire existence revolved around
label: paragraph

line: bleating things: bleating goats that wanted to be fed, and bleating crows that
label: paragraph

line: wanted to steal the food that he gave the bleating goats, and bleating farm
label: paragraph

line: machines that were composed of spinning metal blades and had no discern-
label: paragraph

line: able purpose besides enrolling you in the “Hook Hand of the Month” club.
label: paragraph

line: I asked my friend when he was coming back home, and he said that he was
label: paragraph

line: calling me from the Ann Arbor train station; he had already returned. And
label: paragraph

line: then he let out that foghorn noise, that awful, lingering sound, and I thought,
label: paragraph

line: MAYBE THAT’S THE FIRST SYMPTOM OF COMPOST BIN FLU.
label: paragraph

line: Computer scientists often look at Web pages in the same way that my friend looked at farms.
label: paragraph

line: People think that Web browsers are elegant computation platforms, and Web pages are
label: paragraph

line: light, fluffy things that you can edit in Notepad as you trade ironic comments with your
label: paragraph

line: friends in the coffee shop. Nothing could be further from the truth. A modern Web page is a
label: paragraph

line: catastrophe. It’s like a scene from one of those apocalyptic medieval paintings that depicts
label: paragraph

line: what would happen if Galactus arrived: people are tumbling into fiery crevasses and lament-
label: paragraph

line: ing various lamentable things and hanging from playground equipment that would not pass
label: paragraph

line: OSHA safety checks. This kind of stuff is exactly what you’ll see if you look at the HTML,
label: paragraph

line: | MARCH 2014 | WWW.usenix.oRg
label: paragraph

line: PAge 2
label: paragraph

line: To Wash It All Away
label: heading

line: CSS, and JavaScript in a modern Web page. Of course, no human
label: paragraph

line: can truly “look” at this content, because a Web page is now like
label: paragraph

line: V’Ger from the first “Star Trek” movie, a piece of technology
label: paragraph

line: that we once understood but can no longer fathom, a thrashing
label: paragraph

line: leviathan of code and markup written by people so untrust-
label: paragraph

line: worthy that they’re not even third parties, they’re fifth parties
label: paragraph

line: who weren’t even INVITED to the party, but who showed up
label: paragraph

line: anyways because the hippies got it right and free love or what-
label: paragraph

line: ever. I’m pretty sure that the Web browser is one of the “dens of
label: paragraph

line: iniquity” that I keep hearing about on Fox News; I would verify
label: paragraph

line: this using a Web search, but a Web search would require me to
label: paragraph

line: use a browser, AND THIS IS EXACTLY WHAT BICOASTAL
label: paragraph

line: LIBERAL ELITES WANT ME TO DO.
label: paragraph

line: Describing why the Web is horrible is like describing why it’s
label: paragraph

line: horrible to drown in an ocean composed of pufferfish that are
label: paragraph

line: pregnant with tiny Freddy Kruegers—each detail is horrendous
label: paragraph

line: in isolation, but the aggregate sum is delightfully arranged
label: paragraph

line: into a hate flower that blooms all year. For example, the World
label: paragraph

line: Wide Web Consortium (W3C) provides “official” specifications
label: paragraph

line: for many client-side Web technologies. Unfortunately, these
label: paragraph

line: specifications are binding upon browser vendors in the same
label: paragraph

line: way that you can ask a Gila monster to meet you at the airport,
label: paragraph

line: but that gila monster may, in fact, have better things to do [1].
label: paragraph

line: Each W3C document is filled with alienating sentences that
label: paragraph

line: largely consist of hyperlinks to different hyperlinks. For
label: paragraph

line: instance, if you’re a browser vendor, and you want to add
label: paragraph

line: support for HTML selectors, you should remember that,
label: paragraph

line: during the third step of parsing the selector string, “If result
label: paragraph

line: is invalid ([SELECT], section 12), raise a SYNTAX_ERR
label: paragraph

line: exception ([DOM-LEVEL-3-CORE], section 1.4) and abort
label: paragraph

line: this algorithm.” Such bodice-ripping legalese is definitely
label: paragraph

line: exciting for people who yearn for the dullness of the Cheerios
label: paragraph

line: ingredient list combined with the multi-layered bureaucracy
label: paragraph

line: of the Soviet Union. Indeed, you could imagine a world in which
label: paragraph

line: browser vendors hire legions of Talmudic scholars to under-
label: paragraph

line: stand why, precisely, SYNTAX_ERR is orange and not mauve,
label: paragraph

line: and how, exactly, this orangeness relates to the parenthetic
label: paragraph

line: purpleness of ([DOM-LEVEL-3-CORE]). You could also
label: paragraph

line: imagine a world in which browser vendors do not do this, and
label: paragraph

line: instead implement 53% of each spec and then hope that no
label: paragraph

line: Web page tries to use HTML selectors and then the geolocation
label: paragraph

line: interface and then a <canvas> tag, because that sequence of
label: paragraph

line: events will unleash the Antichrist and/or a rendered Web page
label: paragraph

line: that looks like one of those Picasso paintings that you pretend
label: paragraph

line: to understand, but which everyone wants to throw into an
label: paragraph

line: [1] “Gila Monsters Meet You at the Airport” is the name of a real children’s
label: paragraph

line: book that had an enormous impact on my emotional growth. The book’s
label: paragraph

line: unflinching realism inspired my own series of ill-received children’s
label: paragraph

line: books, such as “Spiders Ate Your Sister That We Never Talk About,”
label: paragraph

line: “Capitalist Advertising Makes You Hate Your Body and Buy Things Made
label: paragraph

line: from Slave Labor,” and “I Could Lie and Say that Your Comic Book Collec-
label: paragraph

line: tion Is Interesting, Or I Could Tell The Truth and Explain Why You Don’t
label: paragraph

line: Get Second Dates.”
label: paragraph

line: | MARCH 2014 | WWW.usenix.oRg
label: paragraph

line: ocean because nobody wants to look at a painting of a blue man
label: paragraph

line: who is composed of isosceles triangles and has a guitar emerg-
label: paragraph

line: ing from his forehead for no reason at all.
label: paragraph

line: Given the unbearable proliferation of Web standards, and the
label: paragraph

line: comically ill-expressed semantics of those standards, browser
label: paragraph

line: vendors should just give up and tell society to stop asking for
label: paragraph

line: such ridiculous things. However, this opinion is unpopular,
label: paragraph

line: because nobody will watch your TED talk if your sense of
label: paragraph

line: optimism is grounded in reality. I frequently try to explain to
label: paragraph

line: my friends why they should abandon Web pages and exchange
label: paragraph

line: information using sunlight reflected from mirrors, or the
label: paragraph

line: enthusiastic waving of colored flags. My friends inevitably
label: paragraph

line: respond with a spiritually vacant affirmation like, “People
label: paragraph

line: invented flying machines, so we can certainly make a good
label: paragraph

line: browser!” Unfortunately, defining success for a flying machine
label: paragraph

line: is easy (“I’M ME BUT I’M A BIRD”), whereas defining success
label: paragraph

line: for a Web browser involves Cascading Style Sheets, a technol-
label: paragraph

line: ogy which intrinsically dooms any project to epic failure. For
label: paragraph

line: the uninitiated, Cascading Style Sheets are a cryptic language
label: paragraph

line: developed by the Freemasons to obscure the visual nature
label: paragraph

line: of reality and encourage people to depict things using ASCII
label: paragraph

line: art. Ostensibly, CSS files allow you to separate the defini-
label: paragraph

line: tion of your content from the definition of how that content
label: paragraph

line: looks—using CSS, you can specify the layout for your HTML
label: paragraph

line: tags, as well as the fonts and the color schemes used by those
label: paragraph

line: tags. Sadly, the relationship between CSS and HTML is the
label: paragraph

line: same relationship that links the instructions for building your
label: paragraph

line: IKEA bed, and the unassembled, spiteful wooden planks that
label: paragraph

line: purportedly contain latent bed structures. CSS is not so much
label: paragraph

line: a description of what your final page will look like, but rather
label: paragraph

line: a loose, high-level overview of what could happen to your page,
label: paragraph

line: depending on the weather, the stock market, and how long it’s
label: paragraph

line: been since you last spoke to your mother. Like a naïve Dungeon
label: paragraph

line: Master untouched by the sorrow of adulthood, you create
label: paragraph

line: imaginative CSS classes for your <div> tags and your <span>
label: paragraph

line: tags, assigning them strengths and weaknesses, and defining
label: paragraph

line: the roles that they will play in the larger, uplifting narrative of
label: paragraph

line: your HTML. Everything is assembled in its proper place; you
label: paragraph

line: load your page in a browser and prepare yourself for a glorious
label: paragraph

line: victory. However, you quickly discover that your elf tag is over-
label: paragraph

line: weight. THE ELF CAN NEVER BE OVERWEIGHT. Even
label: paragraph

line: worse, your barbarian tag does not have an oversized hammer
label: paragraph

line: or axe. Without an oversized hammer or axe, YOUR BARBAR-
label: paragraph

line: IAN IS JUST AN ILLITERATE STEROID USER. And then
label: paragraph

line: you look at your wizard tag, and you see that he’s not an old
label: paragraph

line: white man with a flowing beard, but a young black man from
label: paragraph

line: Brooklyn. FOR COMPLEX REASONS THAT ARE ROOTED
label: paragraph

line: IN EUROPEAN COLONIAL NARRATIVES, YOUR WIZARD
label: paragraph

line: MUST BE AN OLD WHITE MAN WITH A FLOWING BEARD,
label: paragraph

line: NOT A BLACK MAN WITH HIPSTER SHOES AND A
label: paragraph

line: FANTASTIC VINYL COLLECTION. Such are the disasters
label: paragraph

line: PAge 3
label: paragraph

line: To Wash It All Away
label: heading

line: Figure 1: one time, i tried to build a browser-agnostic debugging infra-
label: paragraph

line: structure. i had a client-side Javascript library that could traverse the
label: paragraph

line: Javascript heap and display fun things about the page’s state. My art his-
label: paragraph

line: tory friends told me that console output is for neanderthals, so i made an
label: paragraph

line: HTML gui to display the diagnostic information. The first version of the
label: paragraph

line: gui used the browser’s default layout policies. Much like icarus, i dreamt
label: paragraph

line: of more, so i decided to make A Fancy Layout™. i wrote Css that specified
label: paragraph

line: whether my tags should have static positioning, or floating positioning,
label: paragraph

line: or relative zodiac-based positioning. Here’s what i learned: Never specify
label: paragraph

line: whether your tags should be static or floating or zodiac-based. As soon as a
label: paragraph

line: single tag is released from the automatic layout process, the browser will
label: paragraph

line: immediately go insane and stack random HTML tags along the z-axis, an
label: paragraph

line: axis which apparently is an option even if your monitor can only display
label: paragraph

line: two dimensions. i eventually found a working Css file inside a bottle that
label: paragraph

line: washed up on the beach, and i tweaked the file until it worked for my gui.
label: paragraph

line: Then i went home and cried big man tears that were filled with ninja stars
label: paragraph

line: and that turned into lions when they hit the ground.
label: paragraph

line: | MARCH 2014 | WWW.usenix.oRg
label: paragraph

line: that CSS will wroughth upon thee. Or wrought *at* thee. To be
label: paragraph

line: honest, I don’t know how to conjugate or spell “wrought,” but
label: paragraph

line: my point is undoubtedly understood. See Figure 1 for a con-
label: paragraph

line: crete example of CSS’s wroughtiness. Or CSS’ (no trailing “s”)
label: paragraph

line: wroughtiness. MY NON-CASCADING STYLE MANUALS
label: paragraph

line: FIGHT FOR MY SOUL.
label: paragraph

line: When you’re a Web developer, CSS is just one of your worries.
label: paragraph

line: The aggregate stack of Web technologies is so fragile that
label: paragraph

line: developers just accept a world in which various parts of a Web
label: paragraph

line: page will fail at random times. Apparently this is okay because
label: paragraph

line: e-commerce isn’t a serious thing, and if you really wanted a
label: paragraph

line: secure banking experience, you’d visit the bank in person like
label: paragraph

line: someone from the 1800s instead of accessing a banking Web
label: paragraph

line: site that is constantly (but silently) vomiting execution errors
label: paragraph

line: to the console log (a console log which the browser does not
label: paragraph

line: show by default, because if you knew about it, and you read its
label: paragraph

line: tales of woe, you’d abandon computer science and become a
label: paragraph

line: maker of fine wooden shoes). In Figure 2, I provide an unal-
label: paragraph

line: tered example of such a console log; the log was generated by a
label: paragraph

line: real Web page from a popular site.
label: paragraph

line: The first log entry says that the browser executed a downloaded
label: paragraph

line: file as JavaScript, even though the MIME type of the file was
label: paragraph

line: text/html. Here’s a life tip: when you’re confused about what
label: paragraph

line: something is, DON’T EXECUTE IT TO DISCOVER MORE
label: paragraph

line: CLUES. This is like observing that your next-door neighbor
label: paragraph

line: is a creepy, bedraggled man with weird eyes, and then you start
label: paragraph

line: falling asleep on his doorstep using a chloroform rag as a pillow,
label: paragraph

line: just to make sure that he’s not going to tie you to a radiator and
label: paragraph

line: force you to paint tiny figurines. Here’s how your life story ends:
label: paragraph

line: YOU ARE A PAINTER OF TINY FIGURINES.
label: paragraph

line: The second and third errors say that the page’s JavaScript used
label: paragraph

line: a variable name that is deprecated in strict mode, but accept-
label: paragraph

line: able in quirks mode. How can I begin to explain this delicious
label: paragraph

line: confection of awfulness? Listen: when a man and a woman fall
label: paragraph

line: in love, they want to demonstrate their love to each other. So,
label: paragraph

line: they force browsers to support different types of runtime envi-
label: paragraph

line: ronments. “Standards mode” refers to the unreliable browser
label: paragraph

line: APIs that are described by recent HTML and CSS specifica-
label: paragraph

line: tions. “Quirks mode” refers to the unreliable browser APIs that
label: paragraph

line: were defined by browsers from the Eisenhower administration.
label: paragraph

line: Quirks mode was originally invented because many Web pages
label: paragraph

line: were made during the Eisenhower administration, and the
label: paragraph

line: computing industry wanted to preserve Web-based narratives
label: paragraph

line: about why “the rock and roll” is corrupting our youth. Quirks
label: paragraph

line: mode then persisted because Web developers learned about
label: paragraph

line: quirks mode and used it as an excuse to not learn new skills.
label: paragraph

line: But then some Web developers wanted to learn new skills, so
label: paragraph

line: standards mode was invented to allow these developers to
label: paragraph

line: make old mistakes in new ways. There is also a third browser
label: paragraph

line: mode called “almost standards mode”; this mode is similar to
label: paragraph

line: PAge 4
label: paragraph

line: To Wash It All Away
label: heading

line: Figure 2: They said that i could become anything, so i became the error log of a Web browser. now i own fifteen cats and i wonder where the parties are.
label: paragraph

line: standards mode, except that it renders images inside table cells
label: paragraph

line: using the quirks mode algorithm. For reasons that have been
label: paragraph

line: eaten by a wildebeest, “almost standards mode” is also called
label: paragraph

line: “strict” mode, even though it is less strict than standards mode.
label: paragraph

line: For reasons so horrendous that the wildebeest would not eat
label: paragraph

line: them, there is no completely reliable way to make all brows-
label: paragraph

line: ers load your page using the same compatibility mode. Thus,
label: paragraph

line: even if your page recites the recommended incantations, the
label: paragraph

line: browser may still do what it wants to do, how it wants to do it.
label: paragraph

line: And that’s where babies come from.
label: paragraph

line: The fourth and seventh errors represent uncaught JavaScript
label: paragraph

line: exceptions. In a rational universe, a single uncaught excep-
label: paragraph

line: tion would terminate a program, and if a program continued
label: paragraph

line: to execute after throwing such an exception, we would know
label: paragraph

line: that Ragnarok is here and Odin is not happy. In the browser
label: paragraph

line: world, ignoring uncaught exceptions is called “Wednesday, and
label: paragraph

line: all days not called ‘Wednesday.’” The JavaScript event loop is
label: paragraph

line: quite impervious to conventional notions of software reliabil-
label: paragraph

line: ity, so if an event handler throws an exception, the event loop
label: paragraph

line: will literally pretend like nothing happened and keep running.
label: paragraph

line: This ludicrous momentum continues even if, in the case of
label: paragraph

line: the seventh error, the Web page tries to call init() on an object
label: paragraph

line: that has no init() method. You should feel uncomfortable that
label: paragraph

line: a Web page can disagree with itself about the existence of
label: paragraph

line: initialization routines, but the page is still allowed to do things
label: paragraph

line: | MARCH 2014 | WWW.usenix.oRg
label: paragraph

line: with things. Such a dramatic mismatch of expectations would
label: paragraph

line: be unacceptable in any other context. You would be sad if you
label: paragraph

line: went to the hospital to have your appendix removed, and the
label: paragraph

line: surgeon opened you up, and she said, “I DIDN’T EXPECT
label: paragraph

line: YOUR LIVER TO HAVE GILLS,” and then she proceeded with
label: paragraph

line: her original surgical plan, despite the fact that you’re apparently
label: paragraph

line: a mer-person. Being a mer-person should have non-ignorable
label: paragraph

line: ramifications in the material universe. Similarly, if a Web page
label: paragraph

line: thinks than an object should be initialized, but the object has no
label: paragraph

line: initialization method, the browser shouldn’t laugh about it and
label: paragraph

line: then proceed under the assumption that the rest of the page is
label: paragraph

line: agnostic about whether its objects are composed of folly.
label: paragraph

line: An interpretation of the remaining errors is left as an exercise
label: paragraph

line: to the reader. Note that understanding the eighth error requires
label: paragraph

line: a Ouija board, the eye of a newt, and the whispering of a secret
label: paragraph

line: to a long-lost friend.
label: paragraph

line: At this point, it should be intuitively obvious that different
label: paragraph

line: browsers may or may not produce the same error log for the
label: paragraph

line: same page. In general, if a Web page has more than three bits
label: paragraph

line: of entropy, different browsers will generate extravagantly
label: paragraph

line: unique mappings between the Web developer’s intentions and
label: paragraph

line: the schizophrenic beast palette that browsers use to paint
label: paragraph

line: the world. Thus, picking the “best browser” is like playing
label: paragraph

line: one of those horrid trust-building exercises where you decide
label: paragraph

line: PAge 5
label: paragraph

line: To Wash It All Away
label: heading

line: which three of your five senses you would prefer to lose, and
label: paragraph

line: then your coworkers berate you for making different tradeoffs
label: paragraph

line: than they made, even though there is no partial ordering that
label: paragraph

line: relates scuba diving accidents in which you lose your ears and
label: paragraph

line: eyes, and industrial accidents in which you lose your nose and
label: paragraph

line: tongue. All options are bad options; it’s a world of lateral moves.
label: paragraph

line: Indeed, trying to pick the best browser is like trying to decide
label: paragraph

line: which of your worthless children should inherit the family
label: paragraph

line: business. Little Oliver refuses to accept society’s notion of
label: paragraph

line: what an event handling loop should do, so whenever the user
label: paragraph

line: presses a key on the keyboard, Oliver does not fire one keyPress
label: paragraph

line: event, but instead three keyDown events, a keyUp event, and
label: paragraph

line: the deleted saxophone solo from Mozart’s eighth symphony.
label: paragraph

line: Dearest Fiona, an unrepentant workaholic, designed her
label: paragraph

line: browser so that when you “close” it, the GUI goes away, but
label: paragraph

line: the underlying process lingers in the background, silent and
label: paragraph

line: angry, slowly consuming entries in kernel tables and mak-
label: paragraph

line: ing it impossible to restart the browser without receiving
label: paragraph

line: the error message “Somewhere in this world, another copy of
label: paragraph

line: the browser is running; find Carmen Sandiego and she will
label: paragraph

line: reveal the truth.” Beloved Christopher, in an attempt to make
label: paragraph

line: his browser fast and lightweight, decided to replace his Flash
label: paragraph

line: plugin with code that prints “Shockwave has crashed” and
label: paragraph

line: then immediately dereferences a NULL pointer; this ensures
label: paragraph

line: that most attempts to watch a video will end with you wish-
label: paragraph

line: ing for the simpler audiovisual pleasures of a woodcut or
label: paragraph

line: cave painting. And poor IE6, voted “Least Likely to Succeed
label: paragraph

line: Because IE6 Is Not a Proper Christian Name,” manages to
label: paragraph

line: stumble through the world while surviving more assassination
label: paragraph

line: attempts than Fidel Castro.
label: paragraph

line: Each browser is reckless and fanciful in its own way, but all
label: paragraph

line: browsers share a love of epic paging to disk. Not an infrequent
label: paragraph

line: showering of petite I/Os that are aligned on the allocation
label: paragraph

line: boundaries of the file system—I mean adversarial thunder-
label: paragraph

line: snows of reads and writes, a primordial deluge that makes you
label: paragraph

line: gather your kinfolk and think about which things you need two
label: paragraph

line: of, and what the consequences would be if you didn’t bring fire
label: paragraph

line: ants, because fire ants ruin summers. Browsers don’t require
label: paragraph

line: a specific reason to thrash the disk; instead, paging is a way of
label: paragraph

line: life for browsers, a leisure activity that is fulfilling in and of
label: paragraph

line: itself. If you’re not a computer scientist or a tinkerer, you just
label: paragraph

line: accept the fact that going to CNN.com will cause the green
label: paragraph

line: blinky light with the cylinder icon to stay green and not blinky.
label: paragraph

line: However, if you know how computers work, the incessant pag-
label: paragraph

line: ing drives you mad. It turns you into Torquemada, a wretched
label: paragraph

line: figure consumed by the fear that your ideological system is an
label: paragraph

line: elaborate lie designed to hide the excessive disk seeks of shad-
label: paragraph

line: owy overlords. You launch your task manager, and you discover
label: paragraph

line: that your browser has launched 67 different processes, all of
label: paragraph

line: which are named “browser.exe,” and all of which are launching
label: paragraph

line: desperate volleys of I/Os to cryptic parts of the file system like
label: paragraph

line: | MARCH 2014 | WWW.usenix.oRg
label: paragraph

line: “\roaming\pots\pans\cache\4$$Dtub.partial”, where “\4$$” is
label: paragraph

line: an exotic escape sequence that resolves to the Latvian double
label: paragraph

line: umlaut. You do an Internet search for potential solutions, and
label: paragraph

line: you’re confronted with a series of contradictory, ill-founded
label: paragraph

line: opinions: your browser has a virus; your virus has a virus; you
label: paragraph

line: should be using Emacs; you should be using vi, and this is why
label: paragraph

line: your marriage is loveless.
label: paragraph

line: Of course, the most popular advice for solving any browser
label: paragraph

line: problem is to clear your browser cache. It is definitely true that
label: paragraph

line: emptying the cache will sometimes help, in the same sense that
label: paragraph

line: if you’re poor, kicking a tree will sometimes lead to a hilarious
label: paragraph

line: series of events that conclude with you finding a big bag of
label: paragraph

line: money on the ground with a note that says, “Spend it all! XOXO,
label: paragraph

line: Life.” Unfortunately, kicking a tree does not typically lead to
label: paragraph

line: riches, so your faith-based act of tree assault really just makes
label: paragraph

line: you a savage, tree-kicking monster who will be vilified by chil-
label: paragraph

line: dren and emotionally sensitive adults. Similarly, your arbitrary
label: paragraph

line: clearing of the browser cache, however well-intentioned, is
label: paragraph

line: just a topical anesthetic to briefly dull the pain of existence.
label: paragraph

line: Clearing the cache to fix a Web browser is like when your dad
label: paragraph

line: was driving you to kindergarten, and the car started to smoke,
label: paragraph

line: and he tried to fix the car by banging on the hood three times
label: paragraph

line: and then asking you if you could still smell the carbon monox-
label: paragraph

line: ide, and you said, “Yeah, it’s better,” because you didn’t want to
label: paragraph

line: expose your dad as a fraud, and then both of you rode to school
label: paragraph

line: in silence as you struggled to remain conscious.
label: paragraph

line: So, yes, it would be great if fixing your browser involved actions
label: paragraph

line: that were not semantically equivalent to voodoo. But, on the
label: paragraph

line: bright side, things could always be worse. For example, it
label: paragraph

line: would definitely be horrible if your browser’s scripting lan-
label: paragraph

line: guage combined the prototype-based inheritance of Self, a
label: paragraph

line: quasi-functional aspect borrowed from LISP, a structured
label: paragraph

line: syntax adapted from C, and an aggressively asynchronous
label: paragraph

line: I/O model that requires elaborate callback chains that span
label: paragraph

line: multiple generations of hard-working Americans. OH NO I’VE
label: paragraph

line: JUST DESCRIBED JAVASCRIPT. What an unpleasant turn
label: paragraph

line: of events! People were begging for a combination of Self, LISP,
label: paragraph

line: and C in the same way that the denizens of Middle Earth were
label: paragraph

line: begging Saruman to breed Orcs and men to make Uruk-hai.
label: paragraph

line: Orcs and men were doing a fine job of struggling in their sepa-
label: paragraph

line: rate communities—creating a new race with the drawbacks of
label: paragraph

line: both is not a good way to win popularity contests. But despite
label: paragraph

line: its faults, Java Script has become widespread. Discovering why
label: paragraph

line: this happened is similar to understanding the causes for World
label: paragraph

line: War I—everyone agrees on the top five reasons, but everyone
label: paragraph

line: ranks those causes differently. The basic story is that, in the
label: paragraph

line: ’90s, when JavaScript and Java were competing for client-side
label: paragraph

line: supremacy, Java applets were horrendously slow and lacked
label: paragraph

line: a story for interacting with HTML; in contrast, JavaScript
label: paragraph

line: was only semi-horrendously slow, and it had a bad (but extant)
label: paragraph

line: PAge 6
label: paragraph

line: To Wash It All Away
label: heading

line: story for interacting with HTML. So, Java lost, despite facts
label: paragraph

line: like this:
label: paragraph

line: JavaScript is dynamically typed, and its aggressive type co-
label: paragraph

line: ercion rules were apparently designed by Monty Python. For
label: paragraph

line: example, 12 == “12” because the string is coerced into a num-
label: paragraph

line: ber. This is a bit silly, but it kind of makes sense. Now consider
label: paragraph

line: the fact that null == undefined. That is completely janky; a
label: paragraph

line: reference that points to null is not undefined—IT IS DEFINED
label: paragraph

line: AS POINTING TO THE NULL VALUE. And now that you’re
label: paragraph

line: warmed up, look at this: “\r\n\t” == false. Here’s why: the
label: paragraph

line: browser detects that the two operands have different types, so
label: paragraph

line: it converts false to 0 and retries the comparison. The operands
label: paragraph

line: still have different types (string and number), so the browser
label: paragraph

line: coerces “\r\n\t” into the number 0, because somehow, a
label: paragraph

line: non-zero number of characters is equal to 0. Voila—0 equals
label: paragraph

line: 0! AWESOME. That explanation was like the plot to Inception,
label: paragraph

line: but the implanted idea was “the correctness of your program
label: paragraph

line: has been coerced to false.”
label: paragraph

line: Hello, kind stranger—let me keep you warm during this cold
label: paragraph

line: winter night! Did you know that JavaScript defines a special
label: paragraph

line: NaN (“not a number”) value? This value is what you get when
label: paragraph

line: you do foolish things like parseInt(“BatmanIsNotAnInteger”).
label: paragraph

line: In other words, NaN is a value that is not indicative of a number.
label: paragraph

line: However, typeof(NaN) returns… “number.” A more obvious
label: paragraph

line: return value would be “HAIL BEELZEBUB, LORD OF DARK-
label: paragraph

line: NESS,” but I digress.
label: paragraph

line: By the way, NaN != NaN, so Aristotle was wrong about that
label: paragraph

line: whole “Law of Identity” thing.
label: paragraph

line: Also, JavaScript defines two identity operators (=== and !==
label: paragraph

line: operators) which don’t perform the type coercion that the stan-
label: paragraph

line: dard equality operators do; however, NaN !== NaN. So, basically,
label: paragraph

line: don’t use numbers in JavaScript, and if you absolutely have to
label: paragraph

line: use numbers, implement a software-level ALU. It’s slow, but it’s
label: paragraph

line: the only way to be sure.
label: paragraph

line: Actually, you still can’t be sure. Unlike C++, which uses stati-
label: paragraph

line: cally declared class interfaces, JavaScript uses prototype-based
label: paragraph

line: inheritance. A prototype is a dynamically defined object which
label: paragraph

line: acts as an exemplar for “instances” of that object. For example,
label: paragraph

line: if I wanted to declare a Circle class in JavaScript, I could do
label: paragraph

line: something like this:
label: paragraph

line: //This is the constructor, which defines a
label: paragraph

line: //“radius” property for new instances.
label: paragraph

line: function Circle(radius){
label: paragraph

line: this.radius = radius;
label: paragraph

line: //The constructor function has an object property
label: paragraph

line: //called “prototype” which defines additional
label: paragraph

line: //attributes for class instances.
label: paragraph

line: Circle.prototype.getDiameter = function(){
label: paragraph

line: return 2*this.radius;
label: paragraph

line: | MARCH 2014 | WWW.usenix.oRg
label: paragraph

line: var circle = new Circle(2);
label: paragraph

line: alert(circle.getDiameter()); //Displays “4”.
label: paragraph

line: The exemplar object for the Circle class is Circle.prototype,
label: paragraph

line: and that prototype object is a regular JavaScript object.
label: paragraph

line: Thus, by dynamically changing the properties of that object,
label: paragraph

line: I can dynamically change the properties of all instances of
label: paragraph

line: that class. YEAH I KNOW. For example, at some random
label: paragraph

line: point in my program’s execution, I can do this…
label: paragraph

line: Circle.prototype.getDiameter = function(){
label: paragraph

line: return -5;
label: paragraph

line: …and all of my circles will think that they have a diameter of
label: paragraph

line: less than nothing. That’s a shame, but what’s worse is that
label: paragraph

line: the predefined (or “native”) JavaScript objects can also have
label: paragraph

line: their prototypes reset. So, if I do something like this…
label: paragraph

line: Number.prototype.valueOf = function(){return 42;};
label: paragraph

line: …then any number primitive that is boxed into a Number
label: paragraph

line: object will think that it’s the answer to the ultimate ques-
label: paragraph

line: tion of life, the universe, and everything:
label: paragraph

line: alert((0).valueOf()); //0 should be 0 for all values of 0,
label: paragraph

line: //but it is 42.
label: paragraph

line: alert((1).valueOf()); //Zeus help me, 1 is 42 as well.
label: paragraph

line: alert((NaN).valueOf()); //NaN is 42. DECAPITATE ME AND
label: paragraph

line: //BURN MY WRITHING BODY WITH FIRE.
label: paragraph

line: I obviously get what I deserve if my JavaScript library rede-
label: paragraph

line: fines native prototypes in a way that breaks my own code.
label: paragraph

line: However, a single frame in a Web page contains multiple
label: paragraph

line: JavaScript libraries from multiple origins, so who knows
label: paragraph

line: what kinds of horrendous prototype manipulations those
label: paragraph

line: heathen libraries did before my library even got to run. This
label: paragraph

line: is just one of the reasons why the phrase “JavaScript secu-
label: paragraph

line: rity” causes Bibles to burst into flames.
label: paragraph

line: Much like C, JavaScript uses semicolons to terminate many
label: paragraph

line: kinds of statements. However, in JavaScript, if you forget a
label: paragraph

line: semicolon, the JavaScript parser can automatically insert
label: paragraph

line: semicolons where it thinks that semicolons might ought to
label: paragraph

line: possibly maybe go. This sounds really helpful until you realize
label: paragraph

line: that semicolons have semantic meaning. You can’t just scatter
label: paragraph

line: them around like you’re the Johnny Appleseed of punctua-
label: paragraph

line: tion. Automatically inserting semicolons into source code is
label: paragraph

line: like mishearing someone over a poor cell-phone connection,
label: paragraph

line: and then assuming that each of the dropped words should be
label: paragraph

line: replaced with the phrase “your mom.” This is a great way to cre-
label: paragraph

line: ate excitement in your interpersonal relationships, but it is not
label: paragraph

line: a good way to parse code. Some JavaScript libraries intention-
label: paragraph

line: ally begin with an initial semicolon, to ensure that if the library
label: paragraph

line: is appended to another one (e.g., to save HTTP roundtrips
label: paragraph

line: PAge 7
label: paragraph

line: To Wash It All Away
label: heading

line: during download), the JavaScript parser will not try to merge
label: paragraph

line: the last statement of the first library and the first statement of
label: paragraph

line: the second library into some kind of semicolon-riven statement
label: paragraph

line: party. Such an initial semicolon is called a “defensive semico-
label: paragraph

line: lon.” That is the saddest programming concept that I’ve ever
label: paragraph

line: heard, and I am fluent in C++.
label: paragraph

line: I could go on and on about the reasons why JavaScript is a
label: paragraph

line: cancer upon the world. I know that there are people who like
label: paragraph

line: JavaScript, and I hope that these people find the mental health
label: paragraph

line: services that they so desperately need. I don’t know all of the
label: paragraph

line: answers in life, but I do know all of the things which aren’t
label: paragraph

line: the answers, and JavaScript falls into the same category as
label: paragraph

line: Scientology, homeopathic medicine, and making dogs wear tiny
label: paragraph

line: sweaters due to a misplaced belief that this is what dogs would
label: paragraph

line: do if they had access to looms and opposable thumbs.
label: paragraph

line: In summary, Web browsers are like quantum physics: they offer
label: paragraph

line: probabilistic guarantees at best, and anyone who claims to
label: paragraph

line: fully understand them is a liar. At this stage in human devel-
label: paragraph

line: opment, there are big problems to solve: climate change,
label: paragraph

line: heart disease, the poor financial situation of Nigerian princes
label: paragraph

line: who want to contact you directly. With all of these problems
label: paragraph

line: un solved, Web browsing is a terrible way to spend our time; the
label: paragraph

line: last thing that we should do is run unstable hobbyist operating
label: paragraph

line: systems that download strange JavaScript files from people
label: paragraph

line: we don’t know. Instead, we should exchange information using
label: paragraph

line: fixed-length ASCII messages written in a statically verifiable
label: paragraph

line: subset of Latin, with images represented as mathematical
label: paragraph

line: combinations of line segments, arcs, and other timeless shapes
label: paragraph

line: described by dead philosophers who believed that minotaurs
label: paragraph

line: were real but incapable of escaping mazes. That is the kind of
label: paragraph

line: clear thinking that will help us defeat the space Egyptians
label: paragraph

line: that emerge from the StarGates. Or whatever. I’m an Ameri-
label: paragraph

line: can and I don’t really understand history, but I strongly believe
label: paragraph

line: that Greeks spoke Latin to defeat intergalactic Egyptians.
label: paragraph

line: #TeachTheControversy! Anyways, my point is that browsers
label: paragraph

line: are too complex to be trusted. Unfortunately, youth is always
label: paragraph

line: wasted on the young, and the current generation of software
label: paragraph

line: developers is convinced that browsers need more features, not
label: paragraph

line: fewer. So, we are encouraged to celebrate the fact that browsers
label: paragraph

line: turn our computers into little Star Wars cantinas where every -
label: paragraph

line: one is welcome and you can drink a blue drink if you want to
label: paragraph

line: drink a blue drink and if something bad happens, then maybe
label: paragraph

line: a Jedi will save you, and if not, HEY IT’S A STAR WARS
label: paragraph

line: CANTINA YESSSSS. Space cantinas are fun, but they’re just
label: paragraph

line: a fantasy; they’re just a series of outlandish details stitched
label: paragraph

line: together to amuse and entertain. You have to open your eyes
label: paragraph

line: and see that in the real, non-hyperbolic world that you actually
label: paragraph

line: inhabit, your browser will frequently stop playing a video and
label: paragraph

line: then display flashing epilepsy pixels while making the sound
label: paragraph

line: that TVs make in Japanese horror movies before a pasty sala -
label: paragraph

line: mander child steps out of the screen and voids your warranty.
label: paragraph

line: That’s a thing which could actually happen, and we should
label: paragraph

line: wash it all away.
